can't think of anything to comment so I'm just going to post a pancake recipe.
1 1/2 cups milk
1 egg
2 teaspoons vanilla extract
2 cups White Wings self-raising flour
1/4 teaspoon bicarbonate of soda
1/3 cup caster sugar
25g butter, melted
Whisk milk, egg and vanilla together in a jug. Sift flour and bicarbonate of soda into a bowl. Stir in sugar. Make a well in center. Add milk mixture. Whisk until just combined.
Step 2
Heat a large non-stick frying pan over medium heat. Brush pan with butter. Using 1/4 cup mixture per pancake, cook 2 pancakes for 3 to 4 minutes or until bubbles appear on surface. Turn and cook for 3 minutes or until cooked through. Transfer to a plate. Cover loosely with foil to keep warm. Repeat with remaining mixture, brushing pan with butter between batches.

I stopped drinking at twenty-years-old when I realised that I physically couldn't control the things came out of my mouth after a few drinks. Like, I wouldn't be traditionally drunk; I could think clearly, I knew exactly what was going on around me, but I'd lose the barrier that divided the things that were okay to say and the things that weren't.

For example: every year around christmas time we'd have this party at my aunt's. This particular year my younger cousin had invited her new boyfriend. He was quite a shy kid. He'd barely spoken to anyone all night until eventually he started engaging in small talk with my mother. (Thinking about it, my cousin had probably told him that her aunt (my mother) was lovely, and so she was the only person in my insane family that he felt comfortable speaking with.)

I thought nothing of it until I heard him mention that he wanted to dance with her, or something along those lines. As soon as those words left his mouth I was ready to kill him. In my head he was either ridiculing her, or flirting with her whilst sat next to me in order to provoke me. "Who the fuck does he think he is?"

I patted him on the shoulder, stared him blankly in the eye and said in the most aggressive way possible: "that's my actual fucking mother, you know?" Luckily, he laughed it off in desperation hoping that it was some kind of joke that he'd missed. I smiled to reassure him that that was the case, as the second I'd said it and witnessed his reaction, I understood how out of order I'd been. I was terrified that alcohol had caused that moment of skewed vision and absolute loss of control.

I'm the least confrontational person in the world. I go out of my way to avoid confrontations, yet there I was ready to tear this lad's head off for what was probably nothing. He could have been a cunt, but there's no way I could have known for sure from just that one thing he'd said. I'm still embarrassed about it now, a year later. Haven't drank since.

Your brain balances this effect by decreasing dopamine receptors and increasing glutamate receptors, which have an opposing effect.
